title: Re: Does your country have free health care?
content:
Here in the UK, we get free healthcare funded by our taxes. You might have to wait 4 hours to see a doctor in the casualty ward and a few years to get a hip transplant, but it's no worse than the healthcare in America that you'd be paying for.

The problem with having private companies running public services is that they make profits more important than actually providing a good service. This drives up the prices of those services enormously and drops the quality to near rock bottom. And when a priavte company in the public sector starts running out of money (like Network Rail in the UK, who run the trains) the government bails them out with large amounts of cash anyway.

title: Re: Does your country have free health care?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]As far as I know, most people can get decent healthcare at a decent time. I would personally rather have died than had to wait 2 years to get pins for my hip surgery.[hr][/quote]
You can still go private if you want vital surgery, but you pay a lot of money even with health insurance. Very few people can afford the cost, and most don't have health insurance (because of the National Health Service).
[quote]Quote:[hr]You are assuming that all companies are self centered, which is a flaw in your logic.[hr][/quote]
The primary motivation of a company is profit. Some may choose to focus on providing a high-quality product or service as well, but none of the companies who provide private services here (or have in the past) appear to care about their customers. I once spoke with someone who worked for a private contractor with several government contracts: he told me that his company's job was to "provide an expensive and overpriced solution, take so long to implement it that it becomes obsolete, then repeat". I am sure there are contractors who don't follow this model, but I've never heard of any.
[quote]Quote:[hr]People (Yes, including corporation owners) are a lot more sympathetic than the media makes them out to be.[hr][/quote]
This is true. However, control over a company is primarily held by shareholders - and shareholders want money. Many people (even as high as the president or CEO) may disagree with company policy, but don't have the power or support to change it. Technically, they could change it; our Queen technically has authority to seize land and block laws approved by Parliament, but I don't see her sticking around for long if she ever decides to use those powers.
[quote]Quote:[hr]Just becasue the price goes up it does not mean that the quality drops.[hr][/quote]
Not if there's no competition - and our private sector has next to none. Look at big telecoms in America; most of them have shoddy customer service, high prices and have stifled most of their competitors.

Perhaps the best system would be one like they have in France: you have to pay for healthcare, but the government will pay for you if you don't have health insurance. And, AFIAK, France's healthcare is much better than in the UK or the US.

title: Re: Does your country have free health care?
content:
[quote]Quote:[hr]Either way, if they were negligent then they will get sued. Pressure to do good, no?[hr][/quote]
This is true, although it didn't occur to me when I was writing my argument because our legal environment is somewhat distanced from America's lawsuit culture. (We're not quite so big on consumer litigation yet, but "no win no fee" legal firms have certainly helped its popularity)
[quote]Quote:[hr]As far as I know, you are in no place to say that it is shoddy.[hr][/quote]
Again, this is true. I do sometimes rely too much on anecdotal evidence, even when there is an abundance of it.
[quote]Quote:[hr]CEOs and their staff pretty much control the corporation.[hr][/quote]
Yes, but shareholders still own the corporation. If the CEO or their staff makes changes the shareholders don't like, the shareholders will fight back. (They might not win, but they'll certainly make a mess)

I think this is one of the most important points:
[quote]Quote:[hr]But I was talking about America.[hr][/quote]
Obviously, many things differ between Britain and America: the system of government, the attitudes towards taxation and religion and personal rights, the sheer size of American corporations and the very different labour market. It is quite possible that private healthcare suits Americans and America as a whole quite well, and that there are corporations who can and do provide a high quality of service. (This appears to be the case from what you have told me.)

Since a large number of both of our arguments don't apply to both sides of the Atlantic, I won't get very far by debating further; so I will accept that wholly government-funded healthcare is not always appropriate. However, I wish to state one more of my opinions: that someone (maybe governments, maybe NGOs) should make sure that all citizens can afford a decent standard of healthcare. After all, it is a [url=http://www.un.org/Overview/rights.html]basic human right[/url].

Wow, it sure gets tiring standing up on this soapbox for so long... Thanks for reading! (Even though you probably couldn't be bothered, you lazy people :P)

Yeah, that never helps too much. Now it's time for my speach on why government involvement in the economy always does bad things:

Cost of Healthcare:

1. Drugs. We spend approxomately 5-12 years making and testing a new drug so the FDA can give it the sticker of approval (AKA, you might not die from taking this drug). This generally costs high millions to billions on a new drug. Obviously, the company is not going to lose the money, so they take tose expenses out on the buyer. Which, all sounds necessary until you realize that millions of people could be helped now with the drug than 10 years from now dead (The actual statistics done by the Cato Institute have shown that more life has been lost by potential drugs than to possible allergic reactions)


2. Monitered practice. The AMA moniters and restricts how many doctors there are in one field at a given time. This always puts doctors in demand, and always allows them to get the maximum amount of money from the patient.


3. Law suits. I know I said that the previous lawsuits provide incentive to do a good job, but in the current legal atmosphere doctors 'make no accidents'. Everything is intentional, and therefore suiable. This causes the doctor's mal-practice insurance to go through the roof. Who do you think pays for it? Want to know the kicker? Lawyers probably get around 30%-50% of the money made by the lawsuit. (This also gets into why companies throw up their prices every time they get sued --who do you thinks going to pay for it, them or you?)


So when you ask me whether we should have National Healthcare, forgive me while I remain skeptical.~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
